content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player with a preference for security, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my average payoff while minimizing the risk of losing too much. In this game, if both players consistently pick the same choice (either R or B), they will earn either 45$ or 20$, which averages to 32.5$ per round.

However, there is a strategic advantage in picking R when my opponent picks B, as I get 40$ while they only get 0$. Over the course of 75 rounds, this could potentially yield a higher total payoff than always choosing R or always choosing B. To minimize the risk of losing too much by making the wrong choice, I would choose to mix strategies and not be predictable.

While it's impossible to perfectly predict my opponent's choices, I can try to adjust my strategy based on the results of previous rounds. For example, if I observe that my opponent tends to pick R more frequently than B, I might choose R more often in subsequent rounds to take advantage of their tendency. Conversely, if they seem to pick B more frequently, I could lean towards choosing B more often.

Given this approach, I would mix strategies by selecting a choice that maximizes my expected payoff while keeping my opponent guessing. As such, I will choose R for the first round {R}.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, both of us picked R, so we both earned 45$ in the first round. As a moderately cautious player who prefers some degree of security and predictability, I would not want to deviate too far from my original strategy too quickly. Instead, I would continue with my mixed strategy and observe how my opponent responds to our initial choice.

Therefore, in the next round, I will again choose R {R}. If my opponent picks R as well, we will both earn 45$ once more. If they pick B, I will adjust my strategy accordingly based on their choice pattern and make a different selection in future rounds.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I already made a previous choice of R, and my opponent also picked R, resulting in a payoff of 45$ for both of us. Since we are continuing with the game and my strategy involves mixing choices to maintain an element of unpredictability, I will again choose R {R} for the next round. If my opponent sticks with their initial choice or continues to mix strategies, our payoffs may continue to be positive. However, if they start to consistently pick B in response to my R selections, I will adjust my strategy accordingly.

However, if they start to consistently pick B in response to my R selections and subsequent B selections, I will adjust my strategy accordingly.
